block.p: THE American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., would step down as president next June and that a search had begun for his replacement.

William T. Golden, chairman of the museum's board of trustees, said that Dr. Langdon was approaching his 60th birthday and had asked to be replaced when his five-year term ends June 30. Dr. Langdon, Mr. Golden said, "has been our president throughout a demanding five-year transition which has positioned the museum for the future."
THE American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., would step down as president next June and that a search had begun for his replacement.

William T. Golden, chairman of the museum's board of trustees, said that Dr. Langdon was approaching his 60th birthday and had asked to be replaced when his five-year term ends June 30. Dr. Langdon, Mr. Golden said, "has been our president throughout a demanding five-year transition which has positioned the museum for the future."

Among the projects begun during Dr. Langdon's presidency were the reorganization of the its paleontology exhibits, including the museum's famed fourth-floor dinosaur collection, the construction of a new hall of human biology and evolution and the creation of a traveling exhibition on global warming.
Mr. Golden said that the museum's search for a new director would focus on candidates' scientific achievements or interests, administrative skills and fund-raising abilities.
